results.notes:
These Amanitas were found in the Pine Barrens of NJ. The cap
Was 8 cm across and the overall specimen was 13 cm in height. It had a deep saccate volva with a bulb, a skirt like annulus. It stained yellow with KOH with no distinct odor or staining when cut The the stem was hollow. The subglobose spores were amyloid and measured 7.5-10×8-11 microns. The Q score was in the 1.05-1.125 range.

results.notes:
This is a follow-up collection from MO #421082
Habitat: fruiting from cracks in the bark of living and apparently healthy Quercus alba, usually but not exclusively, either in or immediately adjacent to patches of moss
Cap: diameters 12-27 mm, broadly convex and omphaloid, moist, smooth, white or pale buff with a slightly darker disc, margin often translucent striate, mildly irregular, eventually uplifting
Gills: distant, +/- 16 reaching the stipe, decurrent, white, with multiple ranks of lamellulae, thick, slight crossveins, edges smooth, not marginate
Stipe: length to about 25 mm x 1.5-3 mm thick, dry, equal, strongly curved, pruinose over the entire length, white, cartilaginous, hollow. No evident basal bulb or mycelium.
Flesh: thin, buff in stipe, stipe surprisingly tough
Odor and taste: not distinctive
Spore print: white

results.notes: Collected this unusual mushroom that appears to be a yellow-capped Russula that has been infected by another fungus, possibly Hypomyces, that has deformed the cap into a vertical orientation. The mushroom was extremely flaccid. The morphology is reminiscent of the Lobster Mushroom, H. lactifluorum. Many yellow-capped Russula’s were in the vicinity (see inset photo). Any help with identification of this sample will be appreciated.

results.notes:
Registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017). Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

results.notes:
Registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15-25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. results.notes: Sarasota, FL – Mixed woods (oaks, pines and palms) but closest to pines. The scent was pungently earthy and had a hint of fish. There were 4 specimens within a 2ft submerged in pine needles. The taste was immediately bitter like an aspirin while the texture was very grainy. Flesh was very firm but also brittle, the stem took a lot of pressure before exploding into chunks, the cap snapped cleanly into pieces. The gills bruised a tan to buff on brushing, the trama and gills largely but slowly also changed to the same color after drying.

results.notes: These seem to be a North American variety of Amanita erythrocephala-the redheaded Yellow Dust amanita. The young specimens are bright red orange that fades to a reddish center with a bright yellow orange slightly striate margin. these were found under Norway Spruce in central NJ. The amyloid, ellipsoid spores measure 5-5.5-6 microns. The stipe is yellow above and below the bright yellow annulus. The volva is very pale and fragile withnwhite mycelium.

Cap up to 7.5cm broad, bell-shaped to ovoid with incurved margin when young becoming broadly convex; surface light dull orange becoming deep brownish orange in age; flesh colored like cap but lighter. Gills tawny, ageing to orangish brown; close, broadly adnexed. Stem 4-5cm by 6-14mm, cylindrical; colored like cap but slightly to somewhat lighter, fibrous with darker fibrils in places, especially below the veil when young and near the base in age; center pithy or hollow, colored like outside but darker near the base. Veil cottony, tawny, effervescent. Not producing spores.

spore print darkish tobacco-brown

Microscopy notes:
pleuro common to abundant, narrow and long, from sublageniform with long subcylindrical neck and low belly often buried in hymenium, then flexuose. But sometimes subcylindrical with no belly. Moderatly thin-walled (<1,5um) usually under 1um. Often crystaliferous, but not strongly so at apex, but many times with small specs running down the neck, sometimes naked or almost naked. Sometimes with enlarged apex, faintly subcapitate.
cheilo present, not super abundant but plentyful, mixed shapes, some like pleuro, some with smaller or no belly, often subcapitate to capitate, less crystaliferous, wall thinner. Edge fertile!
both himenial cystidia seem randomly hyaline or yellow with ammonia, walls hyaline or yellowish.
basidia tetrasporic.
upperthird of stipe with only seldom bundles of thin terminal cells, only once one cell remniscent of a cystidia was found next to apex, but not clearly developed in my opinion
secondthird like upper third but less terminal cells even
nothing in lower third

results.notes:
Specimens found four days apart growing in the same area, both the morning after heavy storms. Growing near Quercus.

results.location_name: Midland, Michigan, USA

results.notes:
Cap, approx 5cm , blocky White to cream small appressed scales, slightly depressed or umbonate, slightly resolute.
Gills, white when young, yellowing with age. Broadly attached to the stem.
Stem, Scales reddish brown concentrated near the base.
No distinct odor. Bruises brown. Flesh white.
Growing on rotted stump. Conifers nearby.

I ‘think’ it may be Neolentinus lepideus.
Any suggestions welcome! 😊
